articles.title: THE SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION, INC.
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) is an organization with approximately 100 members of diverse backgrounds, dedicated to fostering public interest in astronomy, conducting amateur research, and promoting the science. Members share expertise in areas like telescope construction, optics, observational techniques, and astrophotography. Owning an optical instrument is not a prerequisite for joining.

articles.title: Activities and Advantages of Membership
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) offers its members and the public a wide range of activities and benefits, including monthly meetings with expert speakers, public observing sessions at various sky parties, and informal indoor gatherings for sharing astronomical knowledge. Membership perks further include a subscription to Sky and Telescope magazine, access to a dedicated library, and equipment loan services, fostering astronomical education and community engagement. Dues are affordable and membership is not required to attend most events.

articles.title: April Evening Skies
articles.summary: This document, created by Abrams Planetarium for April 1980, serves as a stargazing guide for the continental United States. It details the visibility of planets like Venus, Jupiter, Mars, and Saturn, along with 15 first-magnitude stars, and highlights deep-sky objects such as the Orion Nebula and the "Beehive" open cluster. The guide also specifies optimal viewing times for early and late April.

articles.title: Astronomy Day
articles.summary: Astronomy Day, an annual public service event founded and coordinated by the Astronomical Association of Northern California (AANC), was observed across the U.S. and Canada on April 26, 1980. The event, alongside other AANC initiatives like an annual conference and the Messier Club, aims to engage the public through activities such as star parties and by coordinating information on astronomical events.

articles.title: Amateur Societies
articles.summary: This document lists various amateur astronomical societies, primarily in California and Nevada, providing contact phone numbers for each. It notes that these societies typically offer regular meetings, speakers, and activities, with general membership being open to the public. The list serves as a directory for individuals interested in joining local astronomy clubs.

articles.title: Planetariums, Science Centers, and classes on Astronomy
articles.summary: This document provides a directory of planetariums and science centers in the San Francisco Bay Area, including their names and phone numbers. It aims to inform readers about local resources for astronomy education and classes.

articles.title: Telescope-Making Classes
articles.summary: This document lists contact information for organizations offering telescope-making classes in the San Francisco Bay Area. It highlights the Chabot Observatory Telescope Makers Workshop in Oakland and the San Francisco Sidewalk Astronomers, providing resources for individuals interested in learning to build their own telescopes.
